titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the National Republic records, 1918-1960
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-12-02T12:05-0800

change.item: Revised by Sarah Patton to add declassified records series and reorganize the finding aid to reflect the difference between microfilmed and unfilmed material. The oversize box referenced in the extent statement was numbered as #992 and added to the finding aid.
Revised to add Addendum of card files.
Revised to update encoding and add unitid.
Added see also notes, updated coding for OAC, created one dsc.
PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::National Republic records)//EN" "reg_152.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

physdesc.extent: 735 microfilm reels, 76 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize box, 168 card file boxes, 4 sound discs

did.abstract: Clippings, printed matter, pamphlets, reports, indices, notes, bulletins, lettergrams, weekly letters, and photographs relating to pacifist, communist, fascist, and other radical movements, and to political developments in the United States and the Soviet Union.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], National Republic records, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1960.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The National Republic (subtitle, "magazine of fundamental Americanism") was published by the National Republic Publishing Co. in Washington, D.C. It was established in March 1905 and ceased publication with v. 47, no. 11 in March 1960. Until March 1925, it was published under the title National Republican. The magazine, an illustrated monthly, focused on political affairs in the United States, particularly with regard to internal security and communist activities. By the time it ceased publication in 1960, it had achieved a circulation of about 20,000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Clippings, printed matter, pamphlets, reports, indices, notes, bulletins, lettergrams, weekly letters, and photographs relating to pacifist, communist, fascist, and other radical movements, and to political developments in the United States and the Soviet Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clippings, pamphlets, printed matter, and reports, arranged alphabetically by subject. For additional data on organizations, individuals, and subjects identified in this series, see also the general letter folders in Information Files B and C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Some specific printed matter from the collection was not microfilmed (aside from the title pages). These items are now housed in the physical boxes 1-37 (different from the boxes 1-37 listed in the microfilmed material section), with the box numbers they originally came from listed below.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets published by communist organizations, arranged alphabetically by last name of author. Box 407 contains an index listing pamphlets alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The addendum to the National Republic records consists of index card files maintained by the National Republic staff up until 1960. A single Individual Name Index File, comprising 163 card file boxes, is central.

No statement of criteria for inclusion in the file is available, but internal evidence suggests that it is a file of individuals whom the anti-communist journal considered politically objectionable. They include: Communist Party, USA leaders; writers for the Communist Party press; persons mentioned favorably in Communist Party press articles; persons cited in Congressional and state legislative anti-communist reports; officers and sponsors of organizations cited as or alleged to be Communist Party fronts or to be infiltrated by the Communist Party; persons publicly defending the legal rights of alleged communists and/or objecting to anti-communist legislative investigations; signers of petitions to put Communist Party candidates on the ballot in 1940; subscribers to Communist Party press publications in 1942; leaders of other socialist parties or organizations; and public advocates of left-wing causes or policies, including racial integration, immigration, and internationalist and peace policies.

The range of associations triggering an index card is considerable and includes affiliation with a number of liberal, labor and religious organizations that have often not been considered to be within the Communist Party orbit. Among these are the American Civil Liberties Union, Americans for Democratic Action, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and at least one self-proclaimed anti-communist organization, the American Committee for Cultural Freedom. A number of individuals who held high political office (among them former, sitting, and future presidents of the United States) are indexed. The card file constitutes a veritable Who's Who of American communism and of those caught up in the Cold War communist controversy.
Cards cite sources in which the individual's name appears. Most often these are articles in the Communist Party press, but they also include the sources suggested by the categories enumerated above.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Index card file of names of individuals, referenced to sources in which the names appear. Arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of a newspaper clipping from the San Francisco Chronicle, 17 October 1942, "From Where I Sit: The True Tale of a Lady Who Leaves Her Hotel Suite Each Day to Be a Welder," and abstracts of post-war literature produced by the Library of Conference Legislative Reference Service, May 1945.
